Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation of US-based researchers in the international conference "Dynamics, Measures, and Dimensions" held at the Stefan Banach International Mathematical Center in Bedlewo, Poland, April 7-12, 2019. The conference focuses on recent developments and breakthroughs in dynamical systems, ergodic theory, and geometric measure theory. The goal is to bring together international experts in these fields, to foster exchange of ideas and collaborations, and to introduce junior scientists to very active areas of research.

The conference aims to continue the tradition of US-Polish collaboration in dynamical systems and neighboring areas, as it will allow the fostering of face-to-face collaborations that might not occur as readily otherwise. The topics will include but are not limited to: conformal and holomorphic dynamical systems, rational functions and transcendental iteration, thermodynamic formalism, fractal geometry, random dynamical systems, infinite ergodic theory, one dimensional dynamics, orbit counting and Diophantine approximation. The versatile program of plenary talks is complemented by several shorter talks by young researchers, a poster session, a panel for advancing women's career in dynamics, and two crash courses, intended for graduate students and postdocs, that will take place the weekend before the conference. More information is available at: www.impan.pl/en/activities/banach-center/conferences/19-dynamics

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant supported the participation of 14 mathematicians from US institutions in the conference  “Dynamics, Measures and Dimensions", which took place at the Stefan Banach International Mathematical Center in Bedlewo, Poland, April 7–12, 2019. The conference was a major international event with 83 participants from 14 countries, and featured a rich and diverse scientific program focusing on recent developments in Dynamical Systems, Ergodic Theory, and Geometric Measure Theory.  

Thanks to the grant, the, primarily junior, US based participants were able to interact in a vibrant research environment with leading experts in their fields and junior researchers from other countries. Moreover, they had the opportunity to attend three minicourses which preceded the conference and were designed for graduate students and postdocs. These courses were attended approximately 40 early career researchers and they provided a great opportunity for junior researchers to attend introductory lectures related to the themes of the conference by leading dynamicists (and great lecturers) and interact with each other in a more relaxed setting.

Emphasis was given on inviting and supporting female researchers as well as members of other under-represented groups. In particular, the young female researchers who travelled to Poland supported by the grant had inspiring conversations with several senior female Dynamicists from Europe (some of them are well known proponents for the career progression of women in mathematics)  who were plenary speakers in the conference. 

Finally, the project maintained the long standing tradition of US-Polish collaboration in dynamical systems and neighboring areas, by allowing the US based participants to foster face-to-face collaborations with Polish Dynamicists that might not have occurred as readily otherwise.
